abstract: A fusion outcome quasiparticle may be trapped in a potential well of a topological segment. The fusion outcome quasiparticle may be the product of fusion of a first quasiparticle and a second quasiparticle, where the first and the second quasiparticles are localized at ends of a topological segment. The potential well having the fusion outcome quasiparticle trapped therein and a third quasiparticle may be moved relative to each other such that the potential well and the third quasiparticle are brought toward each other. The quasiparticles may be Majorana modes of a nanowire
summary: <SOH> BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF THE DRAWINGS <EOH>The detailed description is described with reference to the accompanying figures. In the figures, the left-most digit(s) of a reference number identifies the figure in which the reference number first appears. The same reference numbers in different figures indicate similar or identical items. FIG. 1 is a schematic diagram of an illustrative qubit encoded with four quasiparticles. FIG. 2 is a schematic diagram of an illustrative fusion tree of a |0) basis state. FIG. 3 is a schematic diagram of an illustrative fusion tree of a |1) basis state. FIG. 4 is a schematic diagram of an illustrative topological system. FIG. 5 is an illustrative fusion tree diagram representing a qubit fusion. FIG. 6 shows illustrative diagrammetric rules (fusion “F-moves”) for quasiparticles. FIG. 7 is a flow diagram of an illustrative topological fusion process showing wire segments (in topological and non-topological phases) with their corresponding chemical potential profiles. FIG. 8 is a schematic representation of illustrative topological segments of nanowire in the context of Majorana operators. FIGS. 9A-9E are schematic illustrations of an exemplary phase gate. detailed-description description="Detailed Description" end="lead"?
title: TOPOLOGICAL QUBIT FUSION
